questions.question_text_1:
Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions: 

I was born into a middle-class Tamil family in the island town of Rameswaram in the erstwhile Madras State. My father, Jainulabdeen, had neither much formal education nor much wealth; despite these disadvantages, he possessed great innate wisdom and a true generosity of spirit. He had an ideal helpmate in my mother, Ashiamma. I do not recall the exact number of people she fed every day, but I am quite certain that far more outsiders ate with us than all the members of our own family put together. 
I was one of many children — a short boy with rather undistinguished looks, born to tall and handsome parents. We lived in our ancestral house, which was built in the middle of the nineteenth century. It was a fairly large pucca house, made of limestone and brick, on Mosque Street in Rameswaram. My austere father used to avoid all inessential comforts and luxuries. However, all necessities were provided for, in terms of food, medicine or clothes. In fact, I would say mine was a very secure childhood, both materially and emotionally. 
The Second World War broke out in 1939, when I was eight years old. For reasons I have never been able to understand, a sudden demand for tamarind seeds erupted in the market. I used to collect the seeds and sell them to a provision shop on Mosque Street. A day’s collection would fetch me the princely sum of one anna. My brother-in-law Jallaluddin would tell me stories about the War which I would later attempt to trace in the headlines of Dinamani. Our area, being isolated, was completely unaffected by the war. But soon India was forced to join the Allied Forces and something like a state of emergency was declared. The first casualty came in the form of the suspension of the train halt at Rameswaram station. The newspapers now had to be bundled and thrown out from the moving train on the Rameswaram Road between Rameswaram and Dhanuskodi. That forced my cousin Samsuddin, who distributed newspapers in Rameswaram, to look for a helping hand to catch the bundles and, as if naturally, I filled the slot. Samsuddin helped me earn my first wages. Half a century later, I can still feel the surge of pride in earning my own money for the first time. 
Every child is born, with some inherited characteristics, into a specific socio-economic and emotional environment, and trained in certain ways by figures of authority. I inherited honesty and self-discipline from my father; from my mother, I inherited faith in goodness and deep kindness and so did my three brothers and sister. I had three close friends in my childhood — Ramanadha Sastry, Aravindan and Sivaprakasan. 
My Childhood - A.P.J Abdul Kalam

But soon India was forced to join the Allied Forces and something like a state of emergency was declared. The first casualty came in the form of the suspension of the train halt at Rameswaram station. The newspapers now had to be bundled and thrown out from the moving train on the Rameswaram Road between Rameswaram and Dhanuskodi. That forced my cousin Samsuddin, who distributed newspapers in Rameswaram, to look for a helping hand to catch the bundles and, as if naturally, I filled the slot. Samsuddin helped me earn my first wages. Half a century later, I can still feel the surge of pride in earning my own money for the first time. 
Every child is born, with some inherited characteristics, into a specific socio-economic and emotional environment, and trained in certain ways by figures of authority. I inherited honesty and self-discipline from my father; from my mother, I inherited faith in goodness and deep kindness and so did my three brothers and sister. I had three close friends in my childhood — Ramanadha Sastry, Aravindan and Sivaprakasan. 
My Childhood - A.P.J Abdul Kalam

props.summary:
### **Exam Summary: Qualifier Level English (Computer-Based Exam)**
This exam tests **English language proficiency** across **vocabulary, grammar, comprehension, and writing skills**. Below is a structured breakdown of the **core topics, concepts, and rules** assessed in the paper.

---

## **1. Reading Comprehension**
### **Key Skills Tested:**
- **Literal comprehension** (factual details from the passage).
- **Inference** (understanding implied meanings).
- **Vocabulary in context** (e.g., "innate," "austere").
- **Fill-in-the-blanks** (grammar + context).

### **Passage Analyzed:**
- Autobiographical excerpt from *"My Childhood"* by **A.P.J. Abdul Kalam**.
- Themes: **Family, childhood memories, socio-economic background, World War II impact**.

### **Core Questions Types:**
| **Type**               | **Example**                                                                 |
|------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Vocabulary**         | Meaning of "innate" (Answer: *Natural*).                                  |
| **Factual Recall**     | Ancestral home built in the **19th century**.                              |
| **Event Timeline**     | WWII started in **1939**.                                                 |
| **Fill-in-the-Blank** | Newspapers thrown between Rameswaram and **Dhanuskodi**.                  |
| **True/False**         | "Narrator had **two** close friends" (False; he had **three**).           |

---

## **2. Grammar & Syntax**
### **A. Tenses & Verb Forms**
| **Concept**            | **Rule**                                                                   | **Example (Exam Question)**                     |
|------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| **Reported Speech**    | Past perfect for past actions: *"I **had been** following his research."* | Q9: *"I had been following your research."*   |
| **Future Perfect**     | *"will have + past participle"*: *"John **will have forgotten**."*        | Q14: *"John will have forgotten all about it."* |
| **Modals (Possibility)** | *"Might"* for uncertain future.                                          | Q8: *"Stealing **might** get us into trouble."* |

### **B. Voice (Active/Passive)**
| **Type**      | **Structure**                     | **Example**                              |
|---------------|-----------------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| **Active**    | Subject + Verb + Object           | *"The engineer **constructed** this house."* (Q11) |
| **Passive**   | Object + *was/were* + Verb (pp)   | *"This house **was constructed** by the engineer."* |

### **C. Articles & Determiners**
| **Concept**       | **Rule**                                                                 | **Example**                              |
|-------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| **"A few of"**    | Used before **pronouns/plural nouns with possession**.                   | Q10: *"**A few of** my books are missing."* |
| **"Few" vs "A few"** | *"Few"* (negative; almost none), *"A few"* (positive; some).             | *"Few people came"* vs. *"A few people came."* |

### **D. Question Tags**
| **Rule**                                                                 | **Example**                              |
|--------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------|
| **Positive statement + negative tag** (and vice versa).                 | Q12: *"I fear you will get into trouble, **don’t I**?"* |
| **Auxiliary verb matches the main clause.**                              | *"She is late, **isn’t she**?"*          |

### **E. Double Negatives**
| **Rule**                     | **Incorrect**               | **Correct**               |
|------------------------------|-----------------------------|----------------------------|
| Avoid double negatives.      | *"I **have not never** been to Canada."* (Q15) | *"I **have never** been to Canada."* |

### **F. Phrasal Verbs**
| **Phrasal Verb** | **Meaning**                     | **Example (Exam Question)**                     |
|------------------|---------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|
| **Let down**     | Disappoint.                     | Q7: *"The coach felt **let down**."*          |
| **Pick on**      | Bully/harass.                   | Q16: *"He **picks on** me in meetings."*      |

---

## **3. Sentence Structure & Common Errors**
### **A. Adverb Placement**
| **Incorrect**               | **Correct**                     | **Rule**                          |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------------|-----------------------------------|
| *"It was a rather **a** painful choice."* (Q13) | *"It was a **rather painful** choice."* | Adverbs (*rather*) modify adjectives. |

### **B. Subject-Verb Agreement**
- Ensure singular/plural consistency.
  - Example: *"She **has** (not have) a book."*

### **C. Prepositions**
- Correct usage in context (e.g., *"missing **from** my cabin"* in Q10).

---

## **4. Writing Skills (Email Writing)**
### **Task:**
- **Formal email** to a principal explaining:
  1. **Reason for break** (e.g., health, family, personal).
  2. **Request to rejoin** (polite tone, clarity).
- **Word limit:** 200 words.
- **Format:**
  - **Subject:** Clear (e.g., *"Request for Re-admission After Break"*).
  - **Salutation:** *"Respected Principal,"*
  - **Body:** 3 paragraphs (introduction, reason, request).
  - **Closing:** *"Sincerely, [Your Name]."*

### **Example Structure:**
```plaintext
Subject: Request for Re-admission After a Brief Break

Respected Principal,

I hope this email finds you well. I am writing to formally request re-admission to [College Name] after a [duration]-month break due to [reason: e.g., medical treatment/family emergency].

[Explain reason briefly with honesty and professionalism. Example: "I had to undergo surgery for [condition], and my doctor advised complete rest. I have now recovered and attached my medical certificate for reference."]

I am eager to resume my studies and complete my coursework. I kindly request you to guide me on the re-admission process and any pending formalities. I assure you of my commitment to academic excellence.

Thank you for your time and consideration. I look forward to your positive response.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]
[Roll Number]
[Contact Information]
```

---

## **5. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **Graph 1: Reading Comprehension Topics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Reading Comprehension] --> B[Vocabulary in Context]
    A --> C[Factual Recall]
    A --> D[Inference]
    A --> E[Fill-in-the-Blanks]
    B --> F["'Innate' = Natural"]
    C --> G[Ancestral home: 19th century]
    C --> H[WWII: 1939]
    D --> I["Narrator's childhood: secure, generous"]
    E --> J["Newspapers: Rameswaram-Dhanuskodi route"]
```

### **Graph 2: Grammar Concepts**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Grammar] --> B[Tenses]
    A --> C[Voice]
    A --> D[Modals]
    A --> E[Determiners]
    A --> F[Question Tags]
    A --> G[Phrasal Verbs]
    B --> H[Reported Speech: "had been + -ing"]
    B --> I[Future Perfect: "will have + pp"]
    C --> J[Active: "Engineer constructed"]
    C --> K[Passive: "Was constructed by"]
    D --> L["Might: uncertain future"]
    E --> M["A few of + pronouns"]
    F --> N["Positive statement + negative tag"]
    G --> O["Let down = disappoint"]
    G --> P["Pick on = bully"]
```

### **Graph 3: Writing Skills**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Email Writing] --> B[Format]
    A --> C[Content]
    B --> D[Subject Line]
    B --> E[Salutation: "Respected Principal"]
    B --> F[Body: 3 Paragraphs]
    B --> G[Closing: "Sincerely"]
    C --> H[Reason for Break]
    C --> I[Request for Re-admission]
    C --> J[Polite Tone]
```
